author: A_Brickset_user
title: Vahki Nuurakh
review:
The Vahki are sort of the police force of Metru-Nui. THese things aren't as tall as Toa Metru (unless they stretch their legs and stand on their toes maybe), but they outsize the 2004 Matoran greatly.

Their heads are very complex objects, consisting of a disk launcher mouth, a very large semi-opaque eye piece, and a small colored skull. They can fire disks, but I like to pose them without them because the disks flop around and drop out alot.

Although the old Toa weapon arms are used, what would be a con is overcome by the new tools. Their claws/staffs are HUGE. By far one of the largest single Lego pieces in the Bionicle line. They extend the arms 2.5 times loonger when added to the old Toa arms, and they're awesome to pose with.

The Vahki can switch between bipedal and quadripedal stances, giving them twice the possibilities for play.

The only cons are the disks not being stable in their mouths and lack of variation (but who cares?). Aside from that, perfect sets.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: Nuurahk
review: Call me biased if you want, but this set exceeded my expectations through and through.  These guys literally put the Toa Metru from earlier this year to shame.  I'd have to say they're some of my favorite sets of six to be released in the entire line so far.  (Yes, I prefer them slightly over the much-beloved Rahkshi.)  The dual staffs serve as great weapons and forlegs, and their 'spider mode' is brilliant.  The disk launcher in the mouth works quite well, firing the projectile a good distance while not being an overly-huge part of the head.  If there's one flaw, it's that the 'eyes' are too far back and on the side of the head, making the little indents in the head piece more eye-like.  (That doesn't really matter to me, though.)  Of the six, Nuurahk is my favorite.  His staffs are the best, both looking cool and able to support him when flat on the ground (like in the cover image), and the new dark-red color for this year goes very well, making him vibrant and menacing in a dark way all at once.  If you get any Vahki this summer, get Nuurahk first.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: Vahki Nuurakh, the best vahki!
review: Nuurakh's attacks may look like nail clippers tho' they are still cool! When I got this set, I was ssssooooo excited! The new pieces, the disk, the kanoka card, anything you can think of(well, not anything you can think of...). This vahki's amanation was cool! You can see it on Bioniclesector01.com, or if you have the set, you can go on Bionicle.com and login into the kanoka club. I think you shall get this set, who ever thinks this vahki sucks, they've gone of track!

author: Gus_263
title: Enforcer of ta-metru
review: The vahki are the enforcers of the island of metru nui. This vahki looks like the another, have a head designed to the function to launch disks. The disks of this is just of the ta-metru. The weapons are really usable, they like claws and are also used in one combination.

author: krysto2002
title: This is bohrok all over again...
review:
As with the bohrok, these guys all share the same exact design, so the opening statement for all 6 will be the same as well. All Vahki have new Bionicle parts (...yay...) and a new feature: they can walk on two legs or four (...yay...) but unlike the bohrok, there really isn't anything to collect except for the colored parts and weapons (...yay...). The Vahki have a gear system allowing their mid torso to swivel (...yay...). The Vahki also have a disk launcher (...yay...) with a different disk for each color (...yay...). 
Still pretty boring since all are the same (...yay, hey wait a second!)

This perticular vahki has a good color scheme, but looks more like a rusted christmas tree. The claws don't move, but that would have been nice... Of the vahki weapons this one scores a 6/10 on the monster meter, so not much to talk about...

author: SaintElsewhere
title: NICE
review: This was my first Vahki. It really painted a nice picture for this subtheme and I would get it all over again. The Vahki are the mechanical enforcers of Metru Nui and can change between bipedal and quadripedal forms, in case you didn't know.

author: KLOKRIECHER
title: LEGO BIONICLE (Vahki) - Nuurakh Review
review:
This is a cool figure to have and it's fun to play with as well.

Box/Instructions

The instruction has 40 pages and there're no mistakes in it.

Parts

This set has a good amount of red pieces which are always good to have future MOC's and/or brickfilms for sure. We also get a disc which glows in the dark.

The build

The build is very nice and easy and we also don't need to worry about stickers as well.

The completed model

[img]http://www.klokriecher.de/gallery_pics/l/8614-1.jpg[/img]


The arms, the legs, the feet and the head can be moved. If you push the mouth of this vahki you can shoot the discs and on the back of the figure you can see a gear which makes the torso able to sviwel. You can also turn the vahki into a crawling position. The design of Nuurakh is very cool, too. I also like the weapons for him which come with this set.

Summary

All in all this set is an great set and I would recommend you to get this. You can find this set on eBay, BrickLink and Amazon for sure. Here is the link where you can check out the full gallery I made for this set on my website: http://www.klokriecher.de


Videos I made of this set:

Stopmotion 1

Stopmotion 2

Review

author: modena
title: My only Vahki!
review:
I got this set for a birthday, and it became my only Vahki.

Pros

  • Fires a Kanoka disk!
  • Great weapons!
  • Great Green head!
  • Transforms into a 4-legged creature!
  • Features swinging arms!

Cons

  • Unstable when in biped form.

Overall:

This was a great set. It involves some Technic parts, making the arms swing. It contains great weapons, which allow the model to walk on 4 legs, like on the picture. It contains a semi-transparent green head shield, which makes it look great! If you are unsure of how to fold it into the 4-legged form, the steps are in the building guide. The set contains a red Kanoka disk, which is fired from the Vahki's jaw. It is not shown in the picture. The only con is that it falls over easily when it walks on 2 legs, and posing is a bit difficult.

Overall, get this set.

author: xboxtravis7992
title: Dr. Strange Vahki: Or how a 25 Year Old Man Learned to Love the Bonk
review:
On a whim one day during a Bricklink purchase I bought this set Nuurakh and one of its sibling sets the white Keerakh on a whim. I had two Vahki sets growing up that I got back in 2004, the black Rorzakh and the blue Bordakh so I was familiar with the line already; but for nostalgia's sake I felt this sudden urge to grab me some more...

Now a few Bricklink orders later and I have the green Vorzakh almost complete now, and will eventually pick up set #6 the brown Zadakh down the road. What was it about these 15 year old sets that drew me back to them on the secondary market all these years later?

First off, its always hard to explain the appeal of these early Bionicle waves to those who judge Lego sets off their builds. A Modular Building this ain't... all six of the Vahki share a clone build, the only differences being the two exclusive staff pieces and the coloring of certain parts. Many early Bionicle waves were like this, the early Toa, Bohrok, Rakshi and Matoron almost were all similar sets with very little differentiation. The Vahki took that to the logical extreme, repeating the build across the entire wave. It wouldn't be until 2007, and not really fully embraced in Bionicle until the 2015 reboot that the sets really broke from the clone build model.

But the clone builds all share a same commonality, playability. Early Bionicle was great at playability, and the Vahki has several basic play features that are a blast to mess around with. The two arms are on central gear, allowing the body to swivel back and forth. The head has a built in disc launcher, placing a Kanoka disk into the launcher and squeezing launcher will toss the disk out a fair distance. Lastly the models show on the box art and other canon Bionicle sources the 'variable geometry' of the Vahki. Much like the Bohrok and their ability to roll into a ball, the Vahki have several poses that represent different play features. They can walk on all fours (like Nuurakh in its boxart), walk on their two hind legs, or place their legs flat with their staffs to their sides into a 'flight mode.' Its simple, but it captivated my imagination as a kid and is still fun to tinker with as an adult. The cloned build also helps in collecting, get a few of these and its easy to imagine them as an army of mooks to face against Toa heroes. Get one color of each, and you have a nice rainbow sample of figures not to disimilar from the trend of collecting monochrome minifigures. 

Packaging is also awesome in early Bionicle. I got this from Bricklink, and the seller had preserved several original features of the packing, including the original plastic canister and the cardboard 'Kanoka Club' card that came with the set. The Kanoka Club codes are useless with the website gone for over a decade now... but are a nostalgic blast to see inside the can. With Lego's push for AR integration with themes like Hidden Side, I am surprised they haven't implemented something similar to the Kanoka Club in modern sets. I don't know if Christian Faber and Advanced were involved much in this wave of Bionicle, but his touch is still very present in the packaging and product presentation.

Of course, they're cheap used on the secondary market... meaning building up an army of these guys is rather affordable. Its a great blast of nostalgia from the past, and with the plenitude of online used Lego shopping options now available now is a great time to dip toes back into collecting the old Bionicle sets. I'd recommend this set to those looking for some fun nostalgia from the mid-2000's.

author: ThoughtLash
title: My First BIONICLE...
review:
My first ever BIONICLE, the Vahki Nuurakh.

Box/Instructions

Nuurakh comes in a canister with it's picture on the front, and info on the back. The instructions are a small booklet.

Parts

Most of the parts in this set originated with the Vahki, and were put to use for most of the last 6 years of BIONICLE. The head can fire a Kanoka disk when you squeeze the sides.

Minifigures

No minifigs.

The build

The Vahki are easy to build, with the only complex parts being the arm swinging function and assembling the head.

The completed model

The completed Nuurahk is an menacing red, silver and green robot ready to track down criminals. The arms swing when a gear on the back is turned, and it can "spit" disks. The Vahki can be folded so that they can crawl on all fours.

Overall opinion

 I highly recommend this set.
